docs.lead_paragraph: Oral diseases, from tooth decay to mouth cancer, threaten the health of poor people, members of minorities, children and the elderly, despite vast improvements in dental care over the past 50 years, according to a study made public today by the surgeon general. The report, the first comprehensive review of the scientific literature on oral health, found that most Americans who are middle-age or younger can expect to keep their teeth for life, largely because fluoride in the drinking water is helping to prevent cavities.

headline.main: 'Epidemic of Oral Disease' Is Found in Poor

docs.abstract: Surgeon Gen David Satcher makes public study finding oral diseases threaten health of poor people, members of minorities, children and elderly, despite vast improvements in dental care over past 50 years; report is first comprehensive review of scientific literature on oral health; it finds most Americans who are middle-age or younger can expect to keep their teeth for life, largely because fluoride in drinking water helps prevent cavities; but study also documents profound and little-noticed disparities in care among nation's most vulnerable citizens, which it calls 'silent epidemic of oral diseases'; finds, for example, that percentage of people with untreated dental cavities is much higher among blacks than whites, that blacks are more likely to have missing teeth and gum disease; disparities are particularly great among children, even among those covered by Medicaid; dentists who care for poor are not surprised by study's findings; photo; chart (M)
docs.snippet: Oral diseases, from tooth decay to mouth cancer, threaten the health of poor people, members of minorities, children and the elderly, despite vast improvements in dental care over the past 50 years, according to a study made public today by the...

docs.lead_paragraph: The outlook for passage of legislation defining patients' rights turned bleak today as House and Senate negotiators issued an unusually negative report on their efforts to strike a compromise. ''These talks are stalled,'' said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, as he walked out of a conference committee meeting this evening. Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, said, ''We are making zero progress.''

headline.main: Negotiators Stall on Patients' Rights Bill

docs.abstract: House and Senate negotiators on legislation defining patients' rights issue unusually negative report on their efforts to strike compromise; at issue is number of peope who should be protected by any new federal standards for health insurance, and whether patients should have new rights to sue health insurance plans for injuries caused by denial of care (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The lawsuit filed by the California Medical Association is an effort to apply the civil provisions of the federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, or RICO. The statute is best known for its use in criminal cases in which the government charges that groups like organized crime or gangs have engaged in a pattern of conspiratorial activity to further their crimes.
docs.abstract: Application of federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) in lawsuit filed by California Medical Association against insurance companies discussed (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, Thomas Frist Jr., said today that the company had changed its name to HCA -- the Healthcare Company. The move is part of an effort by the company, the No. 1 United States hospital chain, to improve an image tainted by the largest federal health fraud fine ever.
docs.abstract: Thomas Frist Jr, chairman of Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, says company has changed its name to HCA--the Healthcare Co; decision is part of an effort by company to improve its tainted image by largest federal health fraud fine ever; Frist says he hopes to reach complete settlement with government on fraud investigation soon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Ehud Barak warned Lebanon and Syria tonight that any cross-border attack on Israeli territory would be considered ''an act of war'' now that Israel has withdrawn from Lebanon, in a rush completed before dawn today. Generals vowed to retaliate against incoming rockets or artillery from Hezbollah guerrillas with strikes against Syrian military targets deep inside Lebanon.

headline.main: Israel Warns Its Neighbors To Rein In Hezbollah

docs.abstract: Prime Min Ehud Barak warns Lebanon and Syria that any cross-border attack on Israel would be considered 'act of war' now that Israel has withdrawn from Lebanon; generals vow to retaliate against rocket or artillery attacks by Hezbollah guerrillas with strikes against Syrian military targets deep inside Lebanon; tension undercuts Israel's enthusiasm over safe return of its troops and end of costly occupation; Israel's northern border is quiet, with few remaining residents ordered into bomb shelters (M)
docs.snippet: Prime Minister Ehud Barak warned Lebanon and Syria tonight that any cross-border attack on Israeli territory would be considered ''an act of war'' now that Israel has withdrawn from Lebanon, in a rush completed before dawn today.     Generals vowed...

docs.lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer withdrew his opposition yesterday to plans by the big nonprofit health insurer, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, to change into a for-profit company. As part of the shift, Empire would set up a multimillion-dollar foundation dedicated to making health care broadly accessible. Empire had offered to give the State Legislature the right to approve or disapprove the conversion and a voice in deciding its future, and to give the public a role in governing the company and the foundation. But hospital and union officials said they would seek to defeat the conversion plan in the Legislature.

headline.main: Spitzer Drops Opposition to Empire Blue Cross's Becoming a For-Profit Company

docs.abstract: New York State Attorney General Eliot L Spitzer withdraws his opposition to plans by big nonprofit health insurer Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield to change into a for-profit company; Empire, as part of shift, will set up multimillion-dollar foundation dedicated to making health care broadly accessible (M)

byline.original: By MILT FREUDENHEIM with WINNIE HU

docs.lead_paragraph: He has survived, for now. But the failed coup attempt against the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, laid bare what everyone in the Capitol has known for years: that many of his troops are deeply dissatisfied with his leadership. Mr. Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, was weakened by the events of the last week, when the majority leader, Michael J. Bragman, tried to overthrow him, culminating in a floor debate Monday that aired much of the 98 Democrats' dirty laundry with jaw-dropping frankness.
docs.abstract: News analysis contends that failed coup attempt against NYS Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver lays bare what everyone in Capitol has known for years: that many of his troops are deeply dissatisfied with his leadership; contends that Silver was politically weakened by Michael J Bragman's attempt to overthrow him (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For all the countless, impassioned speeches Jim Florio has delivered in his quest for the Democratic nomination for New Jersey's United States Senate seat, the most telling two words in his campaign are the ones Mr. Florio has refused to utter: ''I'm sorry.'' Both admirers and critics say it is hardly surprising that Mr. Florio is standing by the single act that has most defined his political career: the $2.8 billion tax increase he pushed through the State Legislature two months after becoming governor.

headline.main: Florio's Style, Like Tax Rise, Remains Issue in Senate Race

docs.abstract: Florio's Style, Like Tax Rise, Remains Issue in Senate Race** Jim Florio, in quest for Democratic Senate nomination in New Jersey, refuses to apologize for pushing through Legislature in 1990 as governor big tax rise that set off voter tirade that swept many Democrats from office; defiantly defends tax move as courageous action to protect Democratic core values, but concedes he should have better explained move to voters; dismisses rival, Jon S Corzine, as rich neophyte trying to buy way into Senate; has been hurt by Corzine's television ads reminding voters of tax rise; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In an odd way, Michael J. Fox said the other day, he feels liberated by his decision to reveal his nearly decade-long battle with Parkinson's disease. ''For me personally, it's been a gift, and I don't mean, 'Hey, rah, I have this thing,' '' he said quietly on the eve of his departure from the ABC show ''Spin City,'' which is broadcasting his final episode of the season tonight.

headline.main: Out of 'Spin City' and Onto a New Stage; Michael J. Fox's Fight With Parkinson's Is Both Personal and Public

docs.abstract: Michael J Fox discusses his fight against Parkinson's Disease, which has forced him to withdraw from regular cast of the TV series Spin City; will remain producer and may appear in one or two episode's next season; is now focusing on Michael J Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Reducing medical costs has become a major goal in the age of managed care, but a new study finds that can be trickier to accomplish than it may seem. One of the main ways to reduce costs is by shortening as much as possible the amount of time people are hospitalized. They are now told to come in as close to surgery as possible, for example, and discharged far earlier than was the practice in the past.

headline.main: VITAL SIGNS: Rx MONEY; Save at One End, Spend at the Other

docs.abstract: Study finds that shortening a heart patients stay at the hospital after surgery may save money at the hospital only by shifting the expense elsewhere (S)
